manuscript.title: Muraqqaʿāt / مرقعات
manuscript.calligrapher_dates: active late 12th century AH / late 18th century CE
manuscript.calligrapher_note: İbrāhīm Ṭāhir (ابراهیم طاهر) is identified as the müstensih (copyist/calligrapher) in the YEK catalogue record for this album (AH 1208/1793–94). No further biographical information has been located for this calligrapher in the standard Ottoman calligraphic registers (e.g., Müstakimzade's Tuhfe-i Hattatin or Rado's Türk Hattatları). The name Ibrahim Tahir is attested in late 18th century Istanbul calligraphic circles, but without a confirming ketebe transcription or comparative palaeographic study it is not possible to identify him with any named master. The date AH 1208/1793–94 places him firmly in the late Ottoman period, within the generation following Ismaʿil al-Zuhdī (d. 1221/1806) and contemporaneous with the final generation before Mustafa Râkım's reform of the nesih and sülüs hands. The album's content (hat meşki — calligraphic exercises in nesih with Arabic letter combinations and hadith texts) is consistent with the production of a practice or teaching album rather than a luxury presentation copy. The colophon or ketebe record requires higher resolution examination or physical inspection to transcribe fully.
manuscript.date_note: The YEK catalogue records the date as AH 1208, corresponding to 1793–94 CE. This is the most precisely dated album in the Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group (cf. pertevniyal_00049, undated; pertevniyal_00050, terminus ante quem 1806 only). AH 1208 falls in the reign of Sultan Selim III (r. 1789–1807), whose court at Istanbul was a center of late Ottoman calligraphic activity. The date is accepted as given; no grounds for cross-dating discrepancy have been identified.
manuscript.place_of_copy_note: No explicit place of copying is recorded. The polychrome mulevven album format with gold cedvel framing and vassale calligraphy mounting, combined with the use of six distinct mulevven paper colors in a coordinated program, is characteristic of high-quality Istanbul production. The Pertevniyal Sultan collection provenance further supports Istanbul origin.
manuscript.format: Muraqqaʿāt (مرقعات) — Ottoman hat meşki calligraphic exercise album with six-color mulevven margin paper program throughout
manuscript.format_note: A bound Ottoman calligraphic album (muraqqaʿāt) of 44 pages (42 yaprak per YEK, plus covers), containing kıtʿa (calligraphic specimen sheets) in nesih (naskh) script with Arabic letter combinations (huruf meşki) and hadith texts. This is the LARGEST album in the Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group (Pertevniyal 00048–00050) and the richest in its color program: at minimum six distinct mulevven (uniformly colored) paper colors have been identified across the thirteen examined text pages. Every examined text page (12 of 12) carries mulevven margin paper with gold cedvel framing and vassale-mounted calligraphy panel — confirming this as a fully mulevven album with no undecorated text pages observed in the sample. The album's content (hat meşki — letter exercises and hadith) is unusual in the context of a luxury mulevven decorative program, suggesting either a high-status teaching album or a commission from a calligraphic atelier. Small round medallion dividers (daire işaret) between text sections have been noted on several pages.
manuscript.script: Nesih (نسخ / Naskh) — per YEK catalogue: 'Arap harfli — Nesih'
manuscript.script_note: The script throughout is nesih (naskh), the standard Ottoman hand for Quran copying and religious text. The calligraphy panels show Arabic letter combinations (huruf meşki: combinations of individual letters as calligraphic exercises) and hadith texts (prophetic sayings). The nesih hand is consistent with late 18th century Ottoman calligraphic practice. No sülüs headline pairing is observed on examined pages — this album is nesih throughout, unlike the sülüs-nesih paired format of pertevniyal_00049 and pertevniyal_00050.

dimensions_mm.note: Outer dimensions 272×198 mm; text area 207×114 mm per YEK catalogue ('272x198-207x114 mm, 42 yk., muhtelif st.'). 'Muhtelif st.' (muhtelif satır = various line counts) confirms variable line layouts across the album's kıtʿa. The page dimensions (272×198 mm) are the largest in the Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group: cf. pertevniyal_00049 (dimensions unrecorded) and pertevniyal_00050 (237×145 mm).

manuscript.folio_count_note: YEK records '42 yk.' (yaprak = leaves, i.e. folios). Total pages 44 (42 text leaves = 84 pages, but the YEK count likely refers to 44 sequential page images including front and back covers, making 42 interior pages). The IIIF sequence runs to p044. All examined IIIF pages are single-page images (recto only), consistent with a single-leaf album format rather than a bifolio codex.
manuscript.notes: Pertevniyal 00048 is the largest and most color-diverse mulevven album in the Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group (00048–00050) and among the richest mulevven murakkaʿ albums in the project corpus. Six distinct mulevven colors have been confirmed across 12 of 12 examined text pages: green (pp002–003), pink/rose (p004), sky blue (pp006, 020), lacivert/navy blue (p035), olive-green/sage (pp010, 015, 030), and orange/saffron (pp025, 040, 044). Every examined page shows gold cedvel (ruling) framing and vassale-mounted calligraphy panels, confirming this as a systematically decorated album. The album is dated AH 1208/1793–94 by its copyist İbrāhīm Ṭāhir — the only precisely dated album in the Pertevniyal sub-group. Fine surface speckles on pp004, 025, and 044 are consistent with zerefşân (gold sprinkling), though resolution limits confirmation. No marbled paper (ebru) is observed on any examined page: this is a PURE mulevven album. A triage prediction of only three colors (pink, gold, green) was significantly revised by visual confirmation: the actual program is at minimum six colors, making this one of the chromatic high points of the Ottoman mulevven album tradition. The library stamp 'Pertevniyal 48' is visible on p002. The YEK record was catalogued by Mücahide Engin under Dewey class 700 (Sanatlar, güzel ve dekoratif sanatlar).

paper_decoration.summary: Pertevniyal 00048 presents a six-color mulevven (uniformly colored paper) program across all examined text pages of a 44-page Ottoman calligraphic exercise album (hat meşki). The color palette documented across 12 examined text pages (pp002–044) comprises: (1) GREEN (yeşil): pp002–003 — vivid bright green filling the full margin around the vassale-mounted calligraphy panel; (2) PINK/ROSE (pembe/gül): p004 — deep saturated pink/rose ground; fine surface speckles visible, consistent with probable zerefşân (gold sprinkling), though resolution is borderline; (3) SKY BLUE (mavi): pp006, 020 — clear bright blue margin; p020 shows more pronounced foxing/age spots; (4) OLIVE-GREEN/SAGE (zeytin yeşili): pp010, 015, 030 — warm olive-gold tone, distinctly different from the bright green of pp002–003, with a muted sage character on p015; (5) ORANGE/SAFFRON (turuncu/safran): pp025, 040, 044 — warm saffron-orange margins; dark speckles on pp025 and 044 may be zerefşân residue or age-related foxing; and (6) LACIVERT/NAVY BLUE: p035 — darker, deeper blue than pp006/020, closer to lapis/navy, representing the most saturated blue tone in the album. Every examined text page carries: (a) gold cedvel (ruling frame) with multi-line system (gold + dark lines); and (b) calligraphy panels vassale-mounted (window-cut) onto the colored margin paper with the cream writing surface clearly visible against the colored ground. Small round medallion dividers (daire işaret) appear between text sections on several pages (pp015, 020). NO marbled paper (ebru) was observed on any examined page: the album employs exclusively mulevven papers. The album is the largest (44 pages) and most chromatically diverse of the three Pertevniyal murakkaʿ albums (cf. pertevniyal_00049: at minimum 7–9 colors but confirmed zerefşân on lacivert; pertevniyal_00050: 2 mulevven + battal ebru mixed). Probable zerefşân on pp004, 025, and 044 requires higher resolution imaging or physical examination to confirm.

technique_terms.ottoman: mülevven kâğıt (altı renk: yeşil, pembe/gül, mavi, lacivert, zeytin yeşili, turuncu/safran); altın cetvel; vassale yöntemiyle monte edilmiş hat paneli; daire işaret (bölüm ayraç madalyonu); zerefşân (muhtemelen, pp004/025/044)
technique_terms.persian: mulavvan (ملوّن) — colored paper; jadval-e tala (جدول طلا) — gold ruling; ṣaḥīfa-ye mulavvan (صحیفه ملوّن) — colored leaf; zarafshān (زر افشان) — gold-sprinkled (probable)
technique_terms.arabic: waraq mulauwwan (ورق ملوّن) — colored paper (six colors: akhḍar / wardi / azraq samāwī / azraq ghamiq / zaytūnī / burhānī); jadwal mudhahhab (جدول مذهّب) — gold-ruled frame; dhahab marshūsh (ذهب مرشوش) — gold-sprinkled (probable)

The YEK record does not carry a dedicated kâğıt özellikleri or tezhip/minyatür decoration field. key_indicators: Explicit date AH 1208/1793–94 in YEK catalogue, confirmed by müstensih attribution to İbrāhīm Ṭāhir — the most precisely dated album in the Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group

Six-color mulevven paper program with gold cedvel framing and vassale mounting throughout 44 pages is characteristic of late Ottoman Istanbul luxury calligraphic album production of the late 18th century
The nesih script (hat meşki — calligraphic exercises) is consistent with Istanbul calligraphic ateliers of the Selim III period (r. 1789–1807)
The Pertevniyal Sultan collection provenance at Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi confirms a high-status Istanbul context — likely a court-adjacent commission

The color palette and formatting closely parallels pertevniyal_00049 (7–9-color mulevven, Istanbul, c. 1695–1725) and pertevniyal_00050 (mulevven + battal ebru, Istanbul, c. 1775–1806), confirming a sustained Istanbul mulevven murakkaʿ production tradition in the Pertevniyal collection
cross_tradition_caveats: The specific paper workshop supplying the six mulevven color papers cannot be identified without physical or documentary evidence
İbrāhīm Ṭāhir has not been identified in standard Ottoman calligraphic registers; a biographical profile cannot be established from current evidence
The probable zerefşân on pp004/025/044 has not been confirmed at physical examination level; the speckles may represent age-related foxing or paper inclusions rather than applied gold

paper.color: Margin papers: six confirmed mulevven (uniformly colored) grounds: (1) vivid bright green (pp002–003); (2) deep pink/rose — probable zerefşân speckles (p004); (3) sky blue (pp006, 020); (4) olive-green/warm sage (pp010, 015, 030); (5) orange/saffron — possible speckles (pp025, 040, 044); (6) lacivert/navy blue (p035). Calligraphy panels throughout: cream/off-white burnished âharlı (sized) paper. 31 pages not yet examined; additional colors may be present.
paper.preparation: Calligraphy panels are written on burnished, sized (âharlı) cream paper consistent with late Ottoman calligraphic practice. Margin papers are separately produced mulevven (solid-dyed) colored sheets onto which the calligraphy panels are window-mounted by the vassale technique. The six mulevven colors are uniformly dyed grounds without textural patterning — no marbling or stenciling observed. Probable zerefşân (gold sprinkling) on the pink/rose (p004), orange/saffron (pp025, 044) pages requires physical confirmation at higher resolution; the speckles are consistent with brush-flicked gold particles (fırça zerefşanı) but could alternatively represent paper inclusions or age spots.
paper.weight: Indeterminate from IIIF images. Standard late Ottoman album-format paper weight expected.
paper.decoration: Six-color mulevven margin papers; gold cedvel (multi-line ruling frame); vassale window-mounted calligraphy panels; probable zerefşân on at least three pages; small round medallion dividers (daire işaret).
paper.paper_type: Eastern/Oriental paper for calligraphy panels (cream âharlı); locally produced solid-dyed mulevven papers for margins (six distinct colors).

ruling.system: Gold cedvel (altın cetvel) framing system throughout all text pages. Multi-line system with gold + dark (black or blue) rules. The gold outer rule is consistently visible against the colored margin ground on all examined pages.
ruling.description: Each text page carries a multi-line gold cedvel surrounding the vassale-mounted calligraphy panel. The system comprises at minimum two lines: a gold outer rule and a dark inner rule, with variations across pages. On p002 (green ground), a clearly visible multi-line gold + dark frame separates the margin from the panel. On pp006 and p020 (sky blue), the gold cetvel is clearly visible against the blue ground. On p035 (lacivert/navy), the gold cetvel stands in high contrast against the dark ground. Small round medallion dividers (daire işaret) appear between text sections on pp015, 020, and possibly other pages. No illuminated corner pieces (koltuk tezhibi) observed on any page.

binding.cover_description: p001: Front binding cover — red/crimson leather with gold-ruled border (cedvel). The surface is worn with scratches and abrasion. A Türkiye Yazma Eserler Kurumu Başkanlığı institutional stamp occupies the center; a library stamp is visible top-left. The back cover (p044 reverse or following page) was not examined in the sampled IIIF sequence. The red/crimson leather binding is distinct from the green binding of pertevniyal_00049 and is unrelated to the decorated paper program.
binding.cover_type: Red/crimson leather with gold-ruled border — binding material assessed as leather
binding.notes: The red leather binding with gold ruling is consistent with late Ottoman utilitarian album bindings of the late 18th century. No flap (mıklep) or elaborate central medallion (şemse) is visible on the front cover in the available image. Physical examination required for full binding assessment. Library stamp 'Pertevniyal 48' is visible on p002 (recto of first text page).

codicology.format: Muraqqaʿāt (مرقعات) — Ottoman calligraphic exercise album (hat meşki) with six-color mulevven program throughout
codicology.condition_summary: The album is generally well preserved. All 12 examined text pages show mulevven margins in vivid, legible condition with clear color saturation. The red/crimson binding cover (p001) shows surface wear (scratches, abrasion). Minor foxing visible on pp020 and 040. The calligraphy panels are legible at IIIF resolution throughout. No catastrophic damage, missing leaves, or major repair campaigns are visible in the examined pages. YEK digital watermark overlay present on all interior pages reduces fine detail readability.

visual_confirmation.visual_evidence: Six distinct mulevven colors confirmed across 12 text pages: green (pp002–003), pink/rose (p004), sky blue (pp006, 020), olive-green/sage (pp010, 015, 030), orange/saffron (pp025, 040, 044), lacivert/navy blue (p035). Gold cedvel framing confirmed on all 12 text pages. Vassale mounting confirmed on all 12 text pages. Probable zerefşân speckles on pp004, 025, 044 — borderline resolution. No ebru detected on any page. Triage prediction of three colors (pink, gold, green) significantly revised: actual program is six colors, substantially richer. Library stamp 'Pertevniyal 48' on p002 confirms identity.
triage_corrections: Triage predicted 'pink, gold, green' mulevven colors. ACTUAL: six colors confirmed (green, pink/rose, sky blue, lacivert, olive-green, orange/saffron) — substantially richer than predicted.
No ebru (marbling) detected despite album format. Pure mulevven album.
Album size (44 pages) confirmed as largest in Pertevniyal murakkaʿ sub-group (00048–00050).

per_type_verdicts.notes: Six distinct mulevven colors confirmed across 12 of 12 examined text pages. Color saturation unambiguous at IIIF resolution. Every text page in the sample carries mulevven paper.
Multi-line gold cedvel confirmed on all 12 examined text pages. Gold outer rule clearly visible against all six mulevven ground colors.
Calligraphy panels window-mounted onto colored margin sheets. Panel edges visible against colored ground on all examined pages.

Fine speckles visible on pp004 (pink), 025 (orange), 044 (orange, on calligraphy panel surface). Pattern consistent with zerefşân (gold sprinkling) but cannot exclude foxing or paper fiber inclusions at 2560×1920 px resolution. Physical examination required.

provenance.waqf: Pertevniyal Sultan collection — associated with Pertevniyal Valide Sultan (c. 1812–1883), mother of Sultan Abdülaziz (r. 1861–1876)
provenance.waqf_note: The Pertevniyal Koleksiyonu at Süleymaniye Yazma Eser Kütüphanesi is the library collection of Pertevniyal Valide Sultan (c. 1812–1883), the mother of Sultan Abdülaziz. She was one of the most powerful and influential imperial women of the Tanzimat era, known for patronizing major mosque construction (Aksaray Valide Camii / Pertevniyal Camii, completed 1871) and for maintaining a substantial personal library. The murakkaʿāt albums in the Pertevniyal Koleksiyonu (nos. 00048–00050) belong to this collection. However, the album's date (AH 1208/1793–94) predates Pertevniyal Valide Sultan's birth by approximately two decades, confirming that it was not originally commissioned by her — it entered the collection by purchase, gift, or inheritance. The mechanism of acquisition is not recorded. Library stamp 'Pertevniyal 48' on p002 confirms current shelfmark and collection assignment.
provenance.notes: The YEK portal records the album under Süleymaniye Yazma Eser Kütüphanesi, Pertevniyal Koleksiyonu, shelfmark 00048, YEK ID 320123, IIIF ID 0000000361867. Catalogued by Mücahide Engin. No previous shelfmarks recorded. The adjacent albums pertevniyal_00049 (shelfmark 00049, YEK ID 320124) and pertevniyal_00050 (shelfmark 00050, YEK ID 320125) are the other murakkaʿ albums in the collection.
